recommendations: Consider CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE) with aggressive hydration and careful contrast volume monitoring.
Explore non-contrast imaging options for the chest if clinically feasible and diagnostic for the acute presentation.
If a non-contrast study is insufficient, carefully consider the risks of CIN in the context of the patient's severe CKD and hypotension.
Ensure adherence to ACR guidelines for contrast media use in patients with reduced renal function.
rationale: Patient has Stage 4 CKD (eGFR 22.0), increasing risk for CIN.
Patient is hypotensive (MAP 57.0 mmHg), which can exacerbate contrast-related renal injury.
Acute presentation of shortness of breath and chest pain strongly suggests PE as a primary concern, necessitating CTA.
Aggressive hydration is recommended per ACR guidelines to mitigate CIN risk.
Non-contrast chest imaging should be considered as an alternative if it can adequately address the acute clinical question.

protocol_selection.name: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
protocol_selection.description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.

protocol_selection.name: Low-Dose CT Chest — Lung Cancer Screening
protocol_selection.description: Low-dose CT of lungs targeting <3 mGy radiation dose while maintaining image quality.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Ideal in patients with renal dysfunction due to non-use of contrast.
